title: The best Arial / Times / Courier for print?
content: Any suggestions as to what would be the best version of Arial, Times New Roman and Courier New for print. High quality offset/un-coated paper/2&4 color. Extended texts and poetry for content. Danke!
author: eastonwest

comments.content: You might want to consider non-bundled fonts. Arial, TNR and Courier have their place - Poetry isn't it.
Can you explain why these typefaces were chosen for your project? I am almost sure we can offer you more appropriate alternatives.

Looks like Verdana and Ikea were not good enough example of bad type choice.  
\_

Sandro

sii: I am trying to use non-bundled fonts. That's why I posed the question in the first place. If you think those choices are nuts, you should read the poetry I'm working with.

Stephen Coles: I'm trying to do good with bad (maybe ubiquitous is a better word?).

I don't have the time, nor the license, to open these typefaces up in FontLab and reconstruct them how I see fit (not to mention I am not a type designer). I can easily go and pick up my copy of Elements…, re-read the Crystal Goblet or thumb through Frutiger's Caracteres if I wanted to use other typefaces.

But I just want a simple answer. Is that so wrong? If there isn't more refined versions of these typefaces available, then just say so.

ravel: You didn't even offer any assistance at all. What gives?

\>But I just want a simple answer. Is that so wrong?

Yes, it's wrong because there isn't a simple answer.

All of those will print clearly in offset. Beyond that answer, it's a matter of suiting the type to the project and the design for the project. There are a million + ways to go, and as Stephen said, for that people would need to know more about the project and the design ideas.

<cite>I don’t have the time, nor the license, to open these typefaces up in FontLab and reconstruct them how I see fit (not to mention I am not a type designer). I can easily go and pick up my copy of Elements…, re-read the Crystal Goblet or thumb through Frutiger’s Caracteres if I wanted to use other typefaces.<cite></cite></cite>

How do you mean to reconstruct those typefaces? They are not something you reconstruct just like that, especially that is not allowed to that and it is not simple to do it, and especially to do it right.

Let's start with this, what feel, what effect you want to generate with? What is the type of poetry, what is it about?  
\_

Sandro

Hi Easton,

as you might know, [Arial](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Arial) is a rip-off of [Helvetica](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Helvetica), with cloned metrics. Its entire raison d'être is a morally questionable one: avoiding license fees (further reading: [The Scourge of Arial](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/www.ms-studio.com/articles.html) by [Mark Simonson](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Mark%2520Simonson)). The only advantages that Arial acually might have over Helvetica – a huge character set and good screen rendering – is probably irrelevant for your project. Hence, I’d say the best Arial for print is a Helvetica. Which one? Well, opinions do vary. [Neue Helvetica](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Neue%2520Helvetica) is cleaner, more consistent across the weights. Some prefer the classic Helvetica, just because of its quirks. [Others, again, praise the URW digitization](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/node/55088#comment-330962).

Times Ten has [oldstyle figures](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/wiki/oldstyle%2520figures) and [small caps](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/wiki/small%2520caps), which makes it a more versatile and dapper choice than the system TNR. More information in [this thread](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/node/42524).

Courier might be the hardest nut. The digital versions of both [Courier](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Courier) and [Courier New](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Courier%2520New) don’t perform very well in print (nor on screen), to say the least. There are so many good alternatives – if you really want to go with a typewriter/monospace for ‘extended texts and poetry’.

Having said that, it is not clear to me if you are looking for the best versions of Arial/Times/Courier that actually go by those names, or rather for good alternatives from the same genres. If the latter is the case, have a look at [Stephen’s lists](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/alternatives/):  
 [Times Alternatives](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/alternatives/times_new_roman/)  
 [Helvetica Alternatives](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/alternatives/helvetica/)  
 [Typewriter](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/genres/typewriter/) and [Monospaced](http://web.archive.org/web/20100201055847/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/genres/monospaced/) faces

Hope this helps.  
F

Was zum Teufel, mein Deutsch ist auch schlecht.

Adding to the "avoid Courier New" comment. The font has hair-line stroke width, which worked okay on screen (before ClearType and grayscale) but which renders very light on high-res output devices. You could go with the bold, or better yet pick another fixed-pitch font.
I find it hard to comprehend why those are the three faces you are limiting yourself to.
